Along with the dress clothes and shoes, you had bought a pair of runners for day-to-day wear, your assorted underwear, and some casual shirts and blouses. The cost of all this had eaten considerably into your limited funds, making your bank appointment and scholarship paperwork all the more important. You had asked Sharon if it was alright if you wore at least part of your purchase now. She was perfectly fine with it, especially after seeing your previous clothing. You donned the new light pink dress suit and dress shoes. Now you looked ready for business.

"Seriously, thank you so much," you said, meaning every word. "I don't know what I'd done had you not been here."

"Think nothing of it, my dear. Just be sure you come back."

"I will. Just one for question before I go; why Madam Zelda's?"

Sharon giggled, and answered, "My Grandmother was a fortune teller, and ran her business out of this building. She had willed the building to me, so when I opened my shop, I decided Madam Zelda wasn't quite ready to leave the world just yet."

Curiosity sated, you waved good bye, and went to the post office. You got a few looks for the sheer number of bags you had, but not as many as you were expecting. The bored clerk at the post office certainly brightened up when you came up to his window. While you were still not used to the leers you were subjected to rather often, at least you were finally better covered up. Getting the box number proved even easier then you'd been expecting, and before your hands could relax from the weight of the bags, you were picking them back up and heading out the door.

You checked your phone. It was 9:51 in the morning. Perfect.
11113111111111.title: To Madam Zelda's Fine Clothing Emporium

111131111111111.content:
You made your way over to the bank, and waited patiently for the final few minutes before opening. You smiled at the security guard as you walked in, and headed over to administration. Greeting the secretary warmly, you said, "Hi! I've got a ten o'clock appointment under Kendall Nelson."

I am so glad I booked it online instead of phone, you thought as the secretary double checked the records.

"Kendall Nelson... ah, here we are," she said as she confirmed your appointment. "Jerry will be with you in a moment. He's just taking a call. You can have a seat over there while you wait." Gratefully, you sat down on one of the soft padded chairs, enjoying resting for the first real moment in quite awhile. Stopping to think about it, it's been a dizzying eighteen hours or so. How many people could say that they switched genders when they went to school? And not in the surgical manner, but in what could only be described as magical. Was it magic that had caused this? And if it wasn't, what was it? And was it permanent? You were certainly tempted to think so; of course, you'd also been tempted to think that you wouldn't shift gender like this in the first place, so who could say?

West coast/east coast thing, maybe? Now there was a thought. If you changed gender every time you flew across country, taking a plane would be an interesting experience. But no, it couldn't be. You'd flown across country and internationally more then a few times without ever having an episode like this.

Or maybe I'm just crazy. That was a chilling thought, but certainly seemed more likely then magic. Had you always been female, and just hallucinated being male? Maybe they'd just finally got your medication just right, and you were just seeing everything correctly for the first time.

No, that can't be, either. All my id's say male on them. Well, except my SIN card. And that was just another mystery. Why had your SIN changed, but not the rest of your wallet? Still, it wasn't all bad. At least you could take solace in the fact that you weren't crazy, it was the world that had stopped making sense.

It was now that, for a brief moment, you felt completely and utterly alone. You'd always been alone, really, but this was a different kind of alone. Your other problems, family or otherwise, weren't unique to you. If you wanted, you could have found somebody to talk to, someone who'd been where you were before and could understand what you were going through. But this was completely, totally different. You had no one to talk to about this. If you ever told anyone, they'd just ship you off to the bin. No one save you would or could know about this. All of life's hurdles, you'd face alone. And that was a very scary thought.

You had almost dozed off (or lapsed into a fear coma) when the secretary's voice shocked you awake. "Miss? He's ready for you now."

******

Jerry turned out to be a middle aged man with salt-and-pepper hair and glasses. He proved to be a jovial and welcoming sort, rising from his chair the moment you entered the room. "Kendall Nelson, I presume? Welcome to our humble city. Glad you found the place okay. Jerry Chou, though you can just call me Jerry. Please, sit down. Help yourself to a cup of coffee."

Jerry had proceeded to pour you a cup before you'd even taken a seat. You accepted it graciously, not wanting to seem rude and filling a caffeine fix at the same time. Mixing in two spoonfuls of sugar and a bit of cream, you sipped quietly as you and Jerry talked business.

"So, your e-mail said you wanted to open an account with us?"

"Two, actually. A checking account, as well as a credit card. I've cancelled my accounts in L.A., save my one credit card. I had paid for my tuition and dorm fees with it, so I can't quite cancel that one just yet. I'll be dealing with my scholarship later today, so my account would be getting a lump sum some time next week. The old credit card gets paid off from that and cancelled afterwards, then I'll just have the card through this bank."

"Not planning to head back that way?"

"Nothing to head back to, sir."

Jerry smiled a little. "Jerry's fine. Not sure I'm a sir." He tapped on his keyboard for a moment. "You have your credit check with you?"

You nodded, and handed him the file your old bank had provided for you. Jerry read a few pages and typed a bit. A sip of coffee, and he repeated the cycle, occasionally filling the silence with some questions. After a while, he leaned away from the keyboard.

"Alright, that should be everything. Your checking account is open, and your bank draft has been accepted. The clerks are getting you a temporary bank card. We'll have your official one mailed to you within five to ten business days. We'll have to do a credit check of our own before we can issue you a credit card, but everything looks good here, so I don't see that being a problem."

"Excellent," you said, leaning forward and standing up from your seat. You gave Jerry's hand a firm shake. "Thank you very much, Jerry. It was a pleasure doing business with you."

"And you as well, Miss Nelson. We look forward to seeing you again."

You left Jerry's office, bags and paperwork in hand. As you grabbed your temporary card, you were all but jumping for joy. I'm doing it, I'm doing it, I'm actually doing it! you thought as you left the bank and walked down the stairs. All that was left was registering your scholarship at the university's office, and then everything would be golden.

Well, almost perfect, you thought as you saw your reflection in a window. Your long hair had re-curled as it had dried, and was now gloriously wavy and bouncing beautifully with each step. Your business clothes accentuated your magnificent curves wonderfully, and while your breasts were no longer threatening to burst out of your clothes, they still certainly filled them to capacity. You took a moment to pull a few strands of hair out of your mouth and tuck them behind your ear. You were still having some issues coming to terms with the fact that this was you. You weren't quite sure you'd ever be fully used to it.

That said, it hadn't even been a full twenty four hours yet. And allowing yourself to sulk and get depressed wouldn't help you at all. You could ponder this conundrum, but later, when you had the time.

Time? You checked your phone, and saw you still had some time before your bus back to campus arrived. Current plan was to head back to campus, deal with the last bit of your financial business, then swing by your room. After dropping off your stuff and changing into your new street clothes, you could come back and grab the rest of your shopping list. Plan made, you began to walk towards the bus stop when a smell stopped you dead in your tracks. You looked across the road, and saw a coffee shop.

A cup of coffee sounds so good right now. You really wanted to stop for a cup, but you needed to catch your bus. But it would be a while before it came...
111131111111111.title: To the Bank

How long could you go on like this? Pretending to be someone else? Eventually you were going to have to tell someone the truth. Who would believe you though? Even your own parents wouldn’t recognize you. You were just as likely to be thrown into a mental hospital.

Before the change you were fair skinned, brown hair, pretty avaeraye build. Our family is a mix of all sorts of traditional European decents so you were just a typical American Mutt. You don't have much time to dwell on that thought. You need to catch your bus, which is now only a couple minutes away. You put a lid on your coffee cup and get up. You know the people are watching you as you leave the coffee shop, but you ignore them. You get to the bus stop merely a minute before the bus pulls up.

This bus is more crowded than the first one was. There's more people staring at you, even though the suit fits and covers you better than the hoodie did, but at least nobody says anything to you this time. You pick at the suit jacket a bit. It's not straining from the size of your breasts, but it's still a bit tighter than you'd like - then again, you'd never been comfortable in suits. You'd have preferred a pant-suit instead of a dress suit, and you wish it weren't pink, but there's nothing to be done.

Meanwhile, your wide hips and round ass, while not nearly as large as your breasts, are still significantly larger than average; and like your breasts are only covered, not hidden, by even the casual clothes. She looks at the clock on the wall. 11:16. "Alright, fine," she says in a dull tone. "Have a seat and someone will be with you shortly."

As instructed, you sit down in one of the chairs by the wall. Almost done, you think. This is actually working. I almost can't believe it. Once you're done here, you'll drop your stuff off in your room, change into some casual clothes, then go back to the mall to get the rest of the stuff on your list.

"Kendall Nelson?" says Janice's bored voice, drawing your attention. "Mr. Alberts will see you now."

He doesn't stare at your chest - if he notices it he hides it well. The two of you enter his office and sit at his desk. "Let's get started," he says.

Mr. Alberts starts typing on his computer. "I'll bring up your profile here," he says. "Now... hm, this is odd."

"What is it?" you ask, though you're certain it has to do with your transformation.

"Well, the information we have for Kendall Nelson is for a male, not a female."

"Really?" you say, feigning surprise. "The security guy said the same thing when I registered coming onto the campus," you add. "He said I was probably entered wrong because of my name."

"That's my hypothesis as well," Mr. Alberts states. "Even so, it needs to be corrected. I need to confirm your identity."

Crap. "What do you mean?" you ask.

"I need to see some identification. Can I see your student ID card?" he asks. You take it out and hand it to him. "Okay, this does have you marked as female," he says. "Do you have another form of identification? The standard is to check two forms of ID."

You take out the new bank card and the old credit card you're planning to cancel. "I just opened a new bank account here earlier this morning," you say, "so I have the temporary bank card from that. I also have an old credit card, but I'll be paying that off with the scholarship money and cancelling it after."

"That'll do," says Mr. Alberts, taking the cards and examining them. He types on his computer for a bit, then hands all three cards back to you. "Okay, that all checks out. I think I see what happened," he says. "Your SIN card has you as female, which means your university profile is too. I checked that, and it is. You said security's list had you as male because of your name, which is probably right. Our side was likely a clerical error; we probably didn't check your scholarship profile against your university profile. I've corrected that, and you'll want to replace any hard copy you have."

Phew, that was close. "Thank you," you say.

Mr. Alberts reaches into his desk and brings out a scholarship info pamphlet. "The details are in here," he says, pushing it across his desk to you. "Tuition is fully covered, aside from the preliminary payment which you've already made. Dorms are included with tuition. If you want to move out of the dorm and rent somewhere, that's not covered. Books are fully covered, as is food from any university cafeteria. Just use your SIN card, I've linked your scholarship to that. Anything else you buy from a university store - notebooks, for example - is half price. Again, use your SIN card, then pay for the rest however you like. Finally, we'll deposit a small amount of money into your bank account each week. I've linked it using the new bank card you showed me, so be sure to use that account. However, you will be required to maintain at least a 3.0 GPA, and to not violate campus rules. If you fail either of these requirements, you will be placed on probation, which lasts one month. If at the end of that time you have met the requirements of the scholarship, probation will be cleared and there will be no problem. However, if your GPA is not above the required level when probation ends, or if you have committed a rules violation while on probation, the scholarship will be withdrawn. If the scholarship is withdrawn you will not have to pay past expenses, but you will be required to pay future expenses in full. Do you understand?"

"I- yes, I understand," you say, surprised at how well this is going.

"Good," he says. "You're all clear then, unless you have any questions."

"No, I don't," you say, putting the info pamphlet in one of your bags. "Thank you." You stand and shake his hand before picking up your bags and leaving the office.

I did it, you think as you leave the building. Holy shit, I actually did it. This is actually going to work. Okay, I still need to get some things at the store, and I'll eventually need to replace my license and passport, but the hard part's done. I can do this.

You make it back to your room and put your bags on the floor, then close and lock the door. You then take off the suit and hang it up in the closet, and change into some more comfortable clothes. Blue jeans and a long-sleeved black shirt. And you swapped the dress suit for sneakers. Sharon had told you that with your chest size it's impossible for you to wear high heels without causing severe damage to your back, so the dress shoes are flats, but sneakers are still more comfortable. You're not sure what you'll do with your old men's clothes, but you can deal with that later (perhaps sell them anonymously on the internet?).

You check your funds. After buying the clothes from Madam Zelda's, you have just under $100 left, until you get a deposit next week. You check your shopping list. Clothes/shoes, bras, shampoo, body wash, conditioner, comb/brush, blow dryer, extra pillows. You cross out clothes, shoes, and bras. You'll need to use most of your scholarship deposits to pay off the old credit card for a while, so you'll be living on a very tight budget. Good thing food and books are covered.

You go back to the bus stop, hoping that you'll be able to get what you need.

“Kids, right?” you mutter something to that effect until the flight attendant goes away. Sandra looks betrayed, but whatever affection you felt for her as a little girl is gone. You’re alone. You’re truly alone. And nothing you say to anyone is going to change that.
